segments.text: So a couple of years after I had graduated and had left the laboratory, I decided to go back to Ohio State for more extensive graduate work.
And I got a job back at the lab where I had worked before.
And so that was where I worked and completed my graduate program then in the early 60s.
Then after I got the PhD from Ohio State, determined that there wasn't really much of a future there for me, largely because there were young men on top of me, so to speak, organizationally.
And so I started looking around, and the department head
There at Ohio State was an old friend of Professor Al Kronk, who was at that time the department head here.
They had both been together at Minnesota way back many years ago.
And so through my department head's good offices there at Ohio State, I learned about the position here at Texas A&M.
I had interviewed a number of other institutions, both public and private.
But I came to Texas A&M and liked what I saw.
I particularly liked the community because I thought it was a good atmosphere in which to raise my kids, and that was a very important matter to me.
And so we came to Texas A&M in the fall of 1964.
Okay.
When did you complete your Ph.D. requirements?
When?
In 64.
At Ohio State.
At Ohio State, right.
What was the topic of your dissertation?
It had to do with similarity parameters in hypersonic flow.
It has to do with chemically reacting flows and reentry processes.
Before we move on, let me ask you a little more about your boyhood years.
What reminiscence do you have of the Depression?
Well, fairly vivid actually.
Although we were
we suffered very little in the Depression.
My father owned a bakery in a small town in Ohio, central Ohio, a little town called Pleasantville, which is, oh, I guess about 40 miles or so almost due east of Columbus.
And dad was a very successful baker, and he had a, you know, had a good business and a good operation there.
That is, our business
Although the bakery was located in Pleasantville, he delivered bakery products to a lot of the other small towns around there.
And so during the Depression, really we did quite well.
My most vivid recollection about it is of those people who did not do well.
I can remember he had brothers, and of course my mother's

family some of them did not do well and i can remember our loading up baskets of of groceries and of course bakery goods but meat and fruit and stuff and and taking them to other members of the family other you know other other family units and i can remember people coming to the bakery and asking for
Well, if they didn't have much money, well, they would buy day-old bread and stale products, or partially stale products.
And I can remember, of course, a lot of drifters, or tramps, as we called them then.
And I'm sure a lot of them good people.
They would come knock on the back door of my parents' house and offer to do work in exchange for a meal.
And I remember lots of those.
But as far as my own family was concerned, of course, I was an only child and typically a spoiled brat.
And so as far as the Depression touching me personally, I was pretty high on the hog.
But I can sure remember others who were not.
What did you think of the New Deal program?
Well, I guess at the time, it was probably the right thing to do.
Of course, there are those who maintain that the country would have rebounded and prospered regardless of how it would have been done, or saying it another way, that it rebounded and prospered
either because of or in spite of Franklin D. Roosevelt's program.
But it worked without a question.
And the country, of course, by the time the war began in 1939, that is the war in Europe, not the war involving the US and the Japanese.
The country actually had begun to rebound pretty well, but it was really the war that finished the recovery from the Depression.
And so it's difficult to really describe how much of that was really produced by New Deal policies and how much of it was not.
But I know my grandfather, my mother's father, worked on the WPA, the Works Project Administration,

which was an element of the New Deal, which involved taking out-of-job, out-of-work workers and placing them in task forces which would do public works kinds of things, build schools and hospitals and roads and things like that.
And I know that helped my grandparents

And my grandfather, of course, he's a very proud man, and he didn't like that too well because it had all the trappings of a government handout, which in effect it was, but it was really in exchange for work, so it certainly was not like a welfare program that does not involve work.
But you have to understand that in that area of Ohio, it's a rock-ribbed conservative area, very conservative.
And so, I guess the prevailing view was there that the country recovered really in spite of the New Deal program and not because of it.
But I'm not sure.
It's like so many of these things.
Certainly there were some good things that came out of it and perhaps some things that were not so good.
Okay.
Now let me, again I'm somewhat confused.
From 1951 through 64 you lived in the Columbus area.
No, we lived most of that time in the Columbus area, but for a time I was working at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, which is over at Dayton, which is like 50 miles away.
That's when I was working for Air Force Intelligence, and that was where I really got my first taste of some of the types of work that we do here at the center now.
Well, in Air Force antennas, was that, were you enlisted in the Air Force when you were working there?

No, I was working as a civilian, and this, and I was not doing any spying or anything like that, but at that time, of course, the, well, it was clear at that time that the Soviets were going to be major adversaries.
Winston Churchill had made his famous Iron Curtain speech
in, what, 47, I guess it was, something like that.
The Soviets were totally intransigent about the situation in Eastern Europe and about the United Nations.
And of course, Korea had begun the Korean War in July of 50, or June of 50, I guess it was.
No, July of 50.
And so it was clear that we were
we were in for some difficulty there.
So the Air Force Technical Intelligence Center had been set up at Wright Field.
It was an offshoot of elements of the old OSS that functioned during World War II.
And then immediately following World War II, there had been an outfit called Project Paperclip, I think it was, which
had been run by Colonel Hal Watson.

And Watson's charge in 1945 and 46 and 47 was to go into Germany and to learn everything that we could learn about advanced aeronautical developments that they had going underway at the end of the war.
Of course, they had several advanced aircraft like the Me 262 and the 163 and so forth that were flying that were superior to anything that we had.
they had been deployed wrong and in insufficient numbers really to affect the outcome of the war.
If they had come along earlier in the war and if Hitler had used them right, it would have been a stickier situation than it was.
But in any event, Watson's group was to do what I would call the first task of technical intelligence.
And of course we knew that because of the way the
political forces at the time divvied up Germany, that the Soviets would have access to a lot of that stuff too.
And indeed they do.
They got, of course, they got a lot of the rocket, the advanced German, the advanced rocket work done by the Germans toward the tail end of the war.
And so I'm not really sure when the Air Force Technical Intelligence Center was set up.
I guess it must have been around 48, something like that.
And so I arrived over there in 1951.
And so my job, I went into the guided missile group.
And so my job was to evaluate data from the Soviet Union about their missile developments, rocket engine development, things like that.
And so I was there until 1953.
And then went back to Ohio State for graduate work.
I had been involved in a dual degree program when I entered Ohio State.
And it was a combination of engineering and mathematics degrees.
That was a program that led to two bachelor's degrees.
And I did that, I guess, perhaps
It may have been that the Depression had more of an effect on my thinking than what I anticipated.
Because in 1947, and of course at that point I was like, what, two years into my engineering undergraduate program.
47, 48 was not a good year for engineering graduates.
They were having trouble getting jobs.
And although I was totally consumed by aerospace engineering, I really wondered if I was going to be able to get a job.

So at that point, I went into the dual degree program to get a degree in mathematics with the view being that perhaps I could go teach math at a junior or community college if I could not get a job as an engineer.
So I had completed all but just, I think, two courses for that math degree.

And so when I left Dayton, Wright-Patterson, the Air Technical Intelligence Service, and came back to Ohio State, let's see, I guess I was enrolled in graduate school for one semester and then I transferred back to undergraduate school for a summer semester and completed the requirements for that math degree and got that in August of
I can't remember, 54, I guess, something like that.
And then transferred back to graduate school, completed my master's degree in 56, and intended at that point to leave and go back to the Air Technical Intelligence Center.
And my senior professor asked me about staying on for a PhD program
Well, of course, I was married by that point.
By that time, I had a family and could do nothing more than take one course at a time.
But he offered me a teaching position, too.
So I was working at the wind tunnel lab and teaching and going to school.
I remember one exchange that I had with him that was rather interesting.
I told him that I didn't think I really wanted to do a PhD because it would take me five years, even starting from the master's level, packing it one course at a time.
And I was 30 at that time.
And I said, shoot.
Von, his name was Von Eschen, and everybody called him Von.
And I said, shoot, Von, in five years, I'll be 35 years old.
And he said, how old will you be in five years if you don't do the PhD?
Which was, I guess, a pretty good line, and he had a good point.
So ultimately, I went ahead, and over an extended period of time, I finally completed the doggone thing.
Actually, of course, it took me longer than five years, but I had a few health problems in the middle of the thing and had to lay out for a year and so forth.
During the time that I was at Ohio State, of course, the space program, the space era burst upon us in 56 with the Soviets launching of the Sputnik.
There was of course great concern about the so-called missile gap that President Kennedy made so much of in the 1960 election, and which in fact did not exist.
But there was great interest in trying to get the U.S. into the space program, and a lot of
a lot of the work that we did there at Ohio State in the laboratory dealt with very high-speed flight, so-called hypersonic flight.
And so we were pretty much on the forefront of at least part of that effort up there.
And so it was a fascinating and stimulating time.
As far as
the aerospace engineering profession.
One of the sub-elements of aerospace engineering is aerodynamics, fluid flow.
There are three other major elements, structures, and propulsion, and flight mechanics.
Well, in very high speed flight, the temperatures that one encounters are so great that it causes chemical reactions in the air.
In other words, air, which is normally, if you're flying at 200 or 300, 400 miles an hour, is just plain old N2 and O2, principally.

When you get to talking about 8,000, 10,000 miles an hour, like would be the case in a reentry process, then the nitrogen and oxygen both dissociate, and the air becomes a very complex mixture at that time.
And so most of our work,

up there involved this sort of new regime of aerodynamics where you had to include chemically reacting flows or you had to include chemical reactions in the calculations in order to predict the aerodynamic characteristics of these vehicles.
That was one of the reasons why some of our early Mercury flights and Gemini flights missed the target, missed the landing area to some extent because we

we could not accurately predict the lift and drag characteristics of those reentry vehicles, largely because of our lack of understanding about the chemical reactions that were occurring around the vehicle.
So as I say, it was a very exciting time to be there and to watch the frontiers of aerospace engineering sort of be
pushed out to encompass the space age.
Very exciting time.

Well, that pretty much reviews the years then at Ohio State, and as I say, when 64 rolled around, I left and came to Texas, and except for a couple of years when I went up to Washington, we've been here ever since.
Okay, when you came to Texas A&M in 1964, in what position did you come?
I came as an associate professor of aerospace engineering.
And you held that until 79?
No.
I became full professor two years later in 66, and then went up to, in 1969, I left Texas A&M.
and went to the University of Maryland to become head of the Aerospace Engineering Department at the University of Maryland right outside of Washington.
I and my family were not happy in Washington.
I guess this goes back to our Midwestern conservative heritage.
We enjoyed the University of Maryland very much.
Which city is that in, the University of Maryland?
Well, it's in College Park, which is just 20 minutes from the Capitol building.
It's just right outside the District of Columbia.
And as I say, we enjoyed the university very much, but we did not enjoy Washington at all.
Just the attitudes and the, of course, that was a very turbulent time, tail end of the 60s, with all of the campus unrest and so forth.
So, we were up there about two years.
My wife, bless her heart, is one of these uncomplaining women.
She just never complains.
Is she also from Ohio?
Yeah.
Well, she was born and raised in LA, but she moved to Ohio when she was young.
Our kids were like, the two girls were like 15 and 14, and the boy was like 10 or 12, something like that.
And they're pretty much like her.
You know, they just don't complain.
But, you know, if your sensors are out, you can tell that things are just not right.
And I had begun to pick up a few of these things.
And I began to ask myself if, in fact, I had made a mistake in coming up there.
And so one Christmas vacation, my two girls, they were then, I guess, 16 and 15.
They had a friend who lived across the street.
And that's what she was a year older and was thinking about starting the university.
That's what triggered this whole sequence.
And so this one Christmas vacation, my two daughters came to me and said, got a proposition for you, Dad.
Fire.

And they said, we know about the high cost of college education, especially if you have to pay out-of-state fees, but do you suppose when our time comes, you could see your way clear to send us to school back in Texas?
And I wasn't really surprised at what they were telling me, but I was surprised that they were telling me, laying it out so openly, indicating some dissatisfaction with that area up there.
And I said, do you mean you'd go to school far away and with a bunch of strangers?
And Chris, Christine, the oldest then, and she was just 16 at that point.
And I can see her like it was yesterday.
She looked at me.
She said, Dad, she said, you know as well as I do, these people up here don't think like we do, which I thought was pretty damn perceptive because she was exactly on target.
They did not think like we did.
The pretentiousness, the imagery, which is peculiar to Washington, was just foreign to us.
That filter's added to the Maryland and Virginia suburbs, too.
Yes, very much.
We lived up in Silver Spring, Maryland, one of the Maryland suburbs up in Montgomery County, but it permeates the area.
So that was really the thing then that tipped the scales.

And so as a matter of fact, when classes resumed and I went back into the University of Maryland right after Christmas, I walked into the dean's office and told him that I had to conclude regrettably that I had made a mistake in bringing my family up there.
I started looking then for another job.
And of course, this was at a time when the space program was on the way down, and the military aerospace was on the way down.
It was not a good time for aerospace engineers.
But there was a job at Cincinnati, University of Cincinnati, and one at Iowa State University, jobs that were open.
And one at Wichita, I guess.
But I was tracking these other jobs.
And of course, aerospace enrollments were down.
And I knew there was nothing in the aerospace engineering department here at Texas A&M for me.
But I told my wife one night, I said, you know, I'm going to write Fred Benson.
He was the dean here for many, many years.
And just see if there would be any sort of a position open for me there.
And so I wrote him.
I told him that I had just flat made a mistake in coming to Maryland, University of Maryland, and that I was looking around for another job.
And so he called me right away, and he said, you forget about going anyplace else.
You're going to come back to Texas A&M.
And so that eventually was what happened.
And of course, it was a great break for me, because it
It gave me a chance to move my family back to an area where they had friends and where we knew the school system.
And of course, it was great to come back to A&M because, as I say, I had been attracted here seven years earlier.
And I felt that I sort of fit in with Texas A&M.
My views are, I think, congruent, shall we say, with the general mood and atmosphere here at A&M.
And so I came back as a special assistant to the dean.
And incidentally, you ought to do an oral history with Fred Benson sometime, who was dean here from 1958 through, what, 1980 or so.
And he's a hell of a guy.
And a lot of people don't understand him very well.
But in any event, when I came here, he made me his special assistant for advanced research efforts.
And his only charge was, I think the College of Engineering and TEES, the Engineering Experiment Station, needs to do some new things.
And he reeled off an incredible set of ideas, some of which were very far out, of things that we might pursue.
And so we did some of those and had some successes and had some failures.
And then about three years later, his associate dean resigned.
And so he asked me to be his associate dean, which I was then, up until
up until he retired, and then I became, I was acting dean until Dr.

Page came aboard in 79, which was the time at which the center was set up, and then I left the dean's office and became director of the center, and of course I still, throughout most of this period, I taught in aerospace engineering, and so I still.
You came back from Maryland to here in what year, 71?
71, right, yeah.
All right, this center was established in 1979 in this location on Highway 21 West.
No, it was originally in town.
And when was it established?
Where was it?
Originally.
Well, this sort of gets into why the center was established.
I suppose we might as well address that.
But let me give you a short answer to the question and then come back and fill in, if I may.
The center was established to do technology policy work primarily at the national level.
The idea here was that when we say strategic technology or strategic research, what we're talking about is sort of long range stuff.
And the ideas for the Center, the idea for the Center, incidentally, well, they started out with a set of ideas that I had, which I'll tell you about shortly.
But then when I gave them to my boss, Fred Benson, why, he, of course, inserted his own ideas.
So it was sort of an amalgam of the two of us, by and large.
And his view, in addition to wanting to do national and international research,
was also to do state-level research.
He felt the state of Texas was too much crisis-oriented.
That is, the state would wait until some problem became enormous, you know, attained crisis proportions, and then they would address it.
And so they'd move from crisis to crisis.
And his view was that we needed to try to identify these problems when they were still on the horizon.
And as they came closer to us, and of course some of them would drop off and some of them would continue to increase in enormity, that we would have solutions that were born of some perspective.
not a solution that was just sort of patched up overnight in response to a crisis.
That's pretty sound thinking, I think.
Well, in any event, so because of his influence, why there was this state charter added to the national charter that the center had.
Well, at that time, the Industrial Economics Research Division, which had been in existence for a long, long time,
The director had resigned, and it had an acting director, and of course they had done an awful lot of state work doing industrial development kinds of things around over the state.
So they had a lot of people who knew the state extensively.
And so that seemed to be a kind of a natural horse to ride into the state policy arena.
Well, they had been set up because of the space crunch on campus.
They had been set up in offices at Bryan Place, which is at the corner of Inwood and Texas Avenue there.

And so when the center was established, I, as the center, went over and became the director of the center, and the industrial economics division was then made the industrial economics group within the center, you see.
And so it was sort of that group that we were sort of wrapped around.
And they were to become our state policy group.
And then after I got over there, why, then we added people to fill out a defense group, so to speak, and went on from there.
So our first location was there at Bryan Place in rented space.
And then
in January of this year, this building, which out here at the Research and Extension Center, which has been a bit of a controversial building.
I guess we don't necessarily need to get into that.
But the building was built without a lot of thought being given to who would occupy it.
And as a result, it was largely unoccupied.
The TTI people had moved into part of it, but this whole wing over here was vacant.
And so, we were ordered to move out here, and so we've been out here since January.
We will have space built for us in the new building, the new engineering building on campus that's being built now.
And we will move back in there in about 18 months, or whenever that building is finished.
The reason for that move is that there is a vault there for us, and we do classified work.
And so we will have that facility there in the new building, which of course will enhance our research capabilities quite a lot.
So that's pretty much the status of the center now.
What will happen to this building when you move back on campus?
I don't really know.
I presume that other university elements will occupy it.
And there's a general mood now, I think, to try to make more use of this research and extension center out here.
And it's a beautiful place to work, depending on what your operations are.
because I had set up two laboratories out here when I was in the Aero Department back in the 60s.
Its primary limitations are, first of all, it's, of course, a long distance to the library.
And we make an awful lot of use of our library here, and that is on the campus.
And so it's difficult there.
The other thing that is a bit of a problem, the center,
Although it is based in engineering, it's part of the engineering experiment station, it really is university-wide operation.
That is to say, we have people from business administration, from history department.
Well, our view is that we have almost 2,000 potential staff members, which means that any faculty member from agriculture to vet medicine is fair game for us.
And so we will put together interdisciplinary teams.
Too many faculty, especially those in business and liberal arts, being 12 miles from the campus is like being in Siberia.
And so one encounters difficulty in getting faculty to come out here, and students, too, for that matter.
And so those are the two principal limitations of the location out here.
Of course, it has advantages.
As you notice, we have no parking problem, and there's no traffic problem.
That part of it is good, and it's nice and quiet.
But we do need to be closer to the library, and we do need to be closer to our staff members who are the faculty and graduate students of the university.
What was originally here before this building was built?
Oh, this was just an open field here.
You said this was a former air base?
Oh, yes.
Yeah, it's a very famous old air base.
Yes, Bryan Air Force Base.
Yes.
I'm not sure that I can tell you the full history of it.
Of course, it was active when I was in the Air Force, in the Army Air Force then up at Waco.
And it was the Central Instructor School.
I'm sorry, that's wrong, Central Instrument School.
Back during War II, the U.S. was divided into three flying training commands.
And this was, of course, this area of the U.S. was the central flying training command.

And instrument flying, that is learning blind flying, as you might call it, learning to fly strictly by instruments alone when you can't, you know, when you're in a cloud and you can't see out of the airplane, you can't see the ground, you can't see anything.
Instrument flying, of course, had been developed
in a rudimentary fashion in the mid-'30s, or by the mid-'30s, I should say.
And of course, it was essential that Air Force pilots know how to fly on instruments.
And so in each one of the flying training commands, there was a central, that is, there was an instrument school.
And all the pilots learned how to fly on instruments through that school.
Bryan Air Force Base here was that school for the Central Flying Training Command.
And so you'll find an awful lot of old-time Air Force pilots who remember when this was an active Air Force base back during World War II.
And then I believe it was closed briefly right after World War II and then reopened.
And when it was reopened, this one must have been in the late 40s or early 50s, perhaps at the time of the Korean thing.
Then they came in and built two new runways, 7,700 foot runways, parallel runways out on the Air Force base here to handle jet aircraft.
And they came in and built these new dormitories or relatively new dorms over here and reactivated the base.
And of course at that time they built an auxiliary field up at Hearn.
I don't know whether you've ever seen
what we affectionately refer to as Hearn International Airport.
But it is, again, I think about a 6,000 or 7,000 foot runway, a beautiful runway, far more than what the city of Hearn would have built to meet its airport needs.
But that was an auxiliary field for this Air Force base here.
And the students would go up there and practice landings and takeoffs and that sort of thing.
And then in 1958,
No, that's wrong.
In 1962, I guess maybe the Air Force base was closed in 58.
I'm not really sure.
There are natives around here that can give you more detail on this than I can.
But about 1962, there was an agreement between the federal government and Texas A&M that A&M would buy this place over the next 20 years.
And it's a rather interesting arrangement,
When Texas A&M gives them, each year they would make an installment payment, the General Services Administration, the federal government, would deed 1 20th of the land to Texas A&M.
Well, in 1982, next year, we will make our final payment, and the old Air Force Base then will be totally Texas A&M's property.
So when I came down here in 64, there were a few operations out here.
Of course, TTI had had their, you know, had started their transportation research work with automobiles, and the ramp and the runways were ideal for that.
But the runways had been fenced off, and the veterinary medicine people had horses out there.

Well, you have to understand that when aviation has been as much of your life as it has been of mine, that there's nothing sadder than, there's only one thing sadder than to see an abandoned airport, and that's to see an abandoned airplane.
And so we, when I, of course, I was brought down here to start a research program in the Department of Aerospace Engineering because they did not have one.
And that was one of the things that I had been pretty good at at Ohio State, was going out and raising money from the outside for research programs.
And so when I came down here and wanted to set up a high-speed aerodynamics program similar to what we'd had up at Ohio State, why, the question was, well, where are you going to house that?
And so there was a building given to me out here
to house that facility.
And then we eventually also reopened one of the hangars over here and set up a flight mechanics laboratory to do actual flight test work to make use of the runways and the facilities out here.
And so it was an old Air Force base, and of course you can still see a lot of the trappings of that.
The hangars, many of the hangars, a couple of the hangars over there were built as temporary hangars back in, I don't know when, 1940, 42, I guess, at the start of World War II.
And they're, well they've deteriorated a little bit, but not a great deal.
They're still in pretty good shape.
course having been around Air Force bases during that period of time I can see a lot of similarity between the way this place looks now and what the Air Force bases looked like back in those days.
Okay could you tell me something about your specific duties today as director about how many people do you supervise how many employees in the strategic technology section?
Well
It's rather difficult to pin down because we're in the process of changing our organizational structure.
Six to eight months ago, we had about 40 people in the center, and now industrial economics has been split off again, and it's no longer part of the center.
There is an education group.
an outfit from the College of Education that has been a part of the center now for about a year, but its activities will terminate in the center in September, and so they will split off.
So taking account of these things that have happened and will happen in the next few weeks, we'll end up with about, well, including faculty who are involved with us on a part-time basis, about 20
uh 20 people all right could we pause here just a moment
